meanings.definition: To make someone feel hurt, upset, or powerless by treating them unfairly or cruelly.
meanings.sent1: The bully victimised the smaller kids on the playground.
meanings.sent2: She felt victimised by her classmates' mean comments.
meanings.sent3: The mischievous kitten victimised the poor dog by stealing its toy.
meanings.sent4: The storm victimised the coastal town, leaving destruction in its wake.
meanings.sent5: The villain in the movie victimised the innocent townspeople, causing fear and chaos.

meanings.definition: To single out someone for mistreatment or persecution.
meanings.sent1: The teacher warned the students not to victimise the new student.
meanings.sent2: The dictator victimised anyone who dared to speak out against him.
meanings.sent3: The mischievous squirrel seemed to victimise the poor birds by stealing their food.
meanings.sent4: The darkness of night seemed to victimise the lone traveler on the deserted road.
meanings.sent5: The rival gang members would often victimise innocent bystanders in their territory.

meanings.definition: To subject someone to harassment or abuse.
meanings.sent1: The online troll would often victimise others with hurtful comments.
meanings.sent2: The supervisor was accused of victimising employees who disagreed with him.
meanings.sent3: The mischievous wind seemed to victimise the fragile flowers in the garden.
meanings.sent4: The corrupt officials would victimise the vulnerable population for their own gain.
meanings.sent5: The relentless sun seemed to victimise the hikers, scorching their skin as they climbed.
